pr_title: feature(core): allow additional platforms in amplify config

timeline.message: implement builder for additional platforms in amplify config

timeline.bodyText:
Maybe consider moving the loadConfigFile method into the Builder and create a builder method for AmplifyConfiguration that creates an instance of that Builder. So the callers would do something like this:
AmplifyConfiguration
    .builder() 
    .fromConfigFile(context)
    .forCategoryType(<category type>)
    .build();

It would be a bit more consistent with how other builders are structured throughout the framework.
timeline.author: rjuliano

replies.bodyText:
The reason for this implementation approach is that we want user to choose one specific way to load in details for the builder. Otherwise, a user may do
AmplifyConfiguration.builder()
    .fromConfigFile(context)
    .fromJson(json) // what does this do?
    .fromConfigFile(anotherContext) // ????
    .build();

My implementation guarantees that one and only one loading approach is used for building a configuration.
replies.author: raphkim

timeline.bodyText:
It's not clear from the name loadConfigFile that this will return a Foo.Builder, instead of a Foo.
I suggest to name this like builderFromConfigFile(...), or something like that.
Alternately, you could do like AmplifyConfiguration.builder(context, resourceId), without playing any naming games. This way it's clear you'll return a builder.

timeline.bodyText:
You don't need to pass this in the JSONObject, if you will keep it as a static method.
The only reason you'd need to populate this in the JSONObject is if the UserAgent is an instance, that you would not be able to access from anywhere else, and has some instance-specific state, right here in this code location.
If you can call UserAgent.string() from any place, you might as well do so from the OkHttp interceptor, directly.

replies.bodyText:
I didn't want to move it as an inner enum, since that makes the user need to specify AmplifyConfiguration.Platform.FLUTTER instead of just Platform.FLUTTER. It also keeps it more hidden from plain sight.
Also, UserAgent is currently configured globally with Map<Platform, String>. Making Platform a part of AmplifyConfiguration would couple it with UserAgent, which you mentioned you would rather not do.
replies.author: raphkim

replies.bodyText: As for whether it belongs inside core package or the outermost package, I'm not sure what the best approach would be. Personally, I thought that Platform specification is one of the most broad concepts in the library, so it might as well belong outside of the core package. I don't think there's a big distinction between com.amplifyframework and com.amplifyframework.core packages as of right now.
replies.author: raphkim
